entry.title: How to Retrieve Approvers for a Custom BO Approval Process (Reporting + PDF Output)?
entry.content:
We are using the standard Approval Process for a Custom Business Object in SAP Cloud for Customer, and we need to retrieve approver information (current approver and full approval chain) for analytics/KPIs and for Outputs (PDF Summary). Standard data sources and SDK functions work only for standard objects, so we cannot access any approval-task details for our custom BO. Has anyone managed to extract this information?

There is plenty of documentation and examples on how to configure an approval process for a custom BO ‚Äî step definitions, conditions, screens, etc. However, once the approval process is activated, we immediately face two major functional gaps:

1) Reporting / Analytics 

We need to display who is the current approver of a custom document.
Normally, for standard objects, this can be done by joining with the data source ‚ÄúApproval Task Details‚Äù (BTMAPPV01). But SAP Support confirmed in our case that this data source contains approval tasks only for standard BOs. So there is no standard reporting option for custom objects, and we need some SDK-based solution ‚Äî but we cannot find any.

2) Approvers for PDF Form

We also need the full approval chain or at least the current approver to show it on the PDF form of the custom document.
Unfortunately, SDK methods that work with standard objects do not work here. For example, GetCurrentStepApproval.Info() on a custom BO results in a system dump (HTTP 500).

Has anyone implemented a requirement where approver details must be retrieved for a custom Business Object? How did you access approval-task or approver information ‚Äî via SDK, a custom service, or another supported method?

Any experience or suggestions would be extremely helpful. Thanks!

entry.title: Re: Production Order Printout Settings
entry.content:
Hi Mahyl,

maybe there is a problem with the sequence if you print direct after saviing. 
During production order creation (CO01) SAP processes the steps in this sequence:

The order header and operations are saved first.
Output (printing) is triggered immediately after the save.
BOM components are calculated and written to the database only afterward.

We print after release and in this moment there are all data present. 
Change output determination so that printing is triggered not during CO01 save, but at Release .

Regards 
Jarda

entry.title: Perform Asset Posting with SAP PaPM
entry.content:
Dear community,

I am working on a SAP Profitability and Performance Management model which generates as output lines to be posted as asset postings (document type
My idea was to use the remote function adapter with the standard Finance General Ledger Items function using the BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST BAPI, but I am struggling to set it right, even by passing additional attributes by mean of the extension2 values.

The test that I set up has to produce one document, with type AA, having two distinct line items: one with account type 'A' (asset) and one with account type 'S' (G/L account).

This is how I am filling the header and GL areas:

Header
Document Type: AA
Posting Date: 04.12.2025
Document Date: 04.12.2025
Company Code: XXXX (one company code defined in the system)
User Name: my username

Line Item 1 (the one to be the document type A)
WBS: a valid wbs element ID
Transaction type: 145
Asset Number: a valid asset number (with zero left padding)
Asset subnumber: 0000
Asset Transaction Type: 100
Account Type: A
Tax Code: a valid tax code
Currency: EUR
Amount: 1000

Line Item 2 (the one to be the document type S)
WBS: a valid wbs element ID (same as line item 1)
GL Account: a valid GL account
Account Type: S
Tax Code: a valid tax code (same as line item 1)
Currency: EUR
Amount: -1000


The values highlighted with purple color are those sent to the BAPI via the extension2 values. When I run the function I get the error: "Required field G/L account was not transferred in parameter ACCOUNTGL". The error refers to the line item 1, but the asset posting should not require a GL account on the account type 'A' as it should be automatically derived.
However, to try overcoming this error I saw online that some people using the same bapi, directly from abap, are filling the G/L account parameter with the asset number itself. I tried doing the same but then the following error comes out: "G/L account <asset number> is not defined in chart of account XYZ".

With a developer we also tried hard coding the posting keys to 70 (debit asset) for line item 1 and 50 (credit entry) for the line item 2, but it didn't change the outcome.

Did anyone also faced the same issue before, or has any experience with asset posting through BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST that could help overcoming this block?

I am available to provide any further detail.

Thank you in advance and best regards,
Francesco

entry.title: Posting date being updated to today‚Äôs date when uploading and approving journal entries
entry.content:
Hi experts,

SAP updates the posting date in the journal entry to today‚Äôs date when uploading journal entries using ‚ÄòVerify General Journal Entries‚Äô (F2547A) followed by ‚ÄòVerify Journal Entries in General Ledger - For Processor (Inbox)‚Äô (F2728).

Does anyone have a solution for how to prevent this from happening? This issue has only occurred since upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2023. Are others experiencing the same problem?

Steps to reproduce:

  1. We upload journal entries using the Upload button in the ‚ÄòVerify General Journal Entries - For Requester' app (Fiori App ID F2547A). In our example, we can see the wanted Posting Date, e.g., 01.12.2025.
  2. Then, the approver approves the journal entry in the ‚ÄòVerify Journal Entries in General Ledger - For Processor (Inbox)‚Äô app (Fiori App ID F2728). SAP posts the journal entry but also incorrectly updates the posting date to today‚Äôs date.

entry.title: Welcome to the Data and Analytics Learning Group
entry.content:
We are very excited to launch this brand-new learning group for all learners of SAP solutions in the Data and Analytics space.

Here you can connect with SAP experts and fellow learners across all data and analytics topics.

The focus of this community is learning. It is not meant to replace the existing SAP Community groups that focus on product-based discussions. Those still exist and should always be used whenever you have a question or want to discuss a topic around a product feature, or need help with trouble-shooting a product-based issue.

This learning community is a place to ask questions and join in discussions around SAP learning content such as courses, learning journeys and certification.

We are here to help you get started and to support you if you run into trouble with topics in the learning content. We are also here to help you prepare for certification. Look out for blog posts from the experts that will soon appear to help with on your learning journey.

The solutions that we cover in this community include:

  • SAP Business Data Cloud
  • SAP Datasphere
  • SAP Analytics Cloud
  • SAP Databricks
  • SAP BW / BW4HANA
  • SAP BusinessObjects
  • SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics
  • SAP HANA Modeling and Data Provisioning
  • Developing data models using ABAP CDS

The community is moderated by SAP experts who are instructors and content developers. This means that you are connecting with those who are very familiar with the course materials and certifications. Remember, these are the guys who developed them!

Make sure you click Join so that you can ask questions, jump into discussions, create blog posts, and add your responses to posts. If you don‚Äôt join you will only be able to browse the posts in this community.

Also, don‚Äôt forget to subscribe to the learning community and individual posts or tags, so you don‚Äôt miss any updates. One final thing: remember to set your notification preferences so you receive emails when a post that you subscribed to has been updated.

SAP Community provides a separate place for discussions and questions, but we thought we‚Äôd try and simply things for you by combining them. After all, a question often leads to a discussion and vice-versa. So please use the Discussions button to start a discussion and to ask questions.

Why not introduce yourself to members of this community and let us know a little about your SAP journey? What brought you here? What are you hoping to get from this community? Simply post a reply here and let us know.

Make sure you spread the word about this community. Post a link in your social media so that we can build a vibrant and effective community of data and analytics learners.

As with all SAP communities, we want this to be a safe space for our members. Please familiarize yourself with the SAP Community Rules of Engagement

Welcome aboard. Let‚Äôs get connected!

Mark Green
Moderator: SAP Community - Data and Analytics Learning Group

entry.title: Beta Version of Application Vulnerability Report for SAP BTP Now Available
entry.content:
Earlier this month, we released the application vulnerability report (beta) for SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). You can use this new service to detect and remediate open-source application vulnerabilities in your SAP BTP deployed applications. 

What is this new service all about? 

Frequent security issues in open-source components endanger business data in customer deployed applications. Customers are responsible for performing vigilant patch and vulnerability management. By leveraging the new application vulnerability report for SAP BTP, open-source vulnerabilities in your Cloud Foundry applications can be detected and remediated. It's crucial to fix such vulnerabilities quickly, as attackers are usually aware of them and might try to break into vulnerable systems. 

What does the new application vulnerability report service offer you? 

The application vulnerability report supports you in the detection of vulnerabilities in custom applications during runtime. It enables you to act on criticality and other provided vulnerability details, like mitigation recommendations.  

If we take a closer look at the process, the service scans the applications using a proprietary scanning layer that utilizes open-source scanners as well as custom SAP BTP-specific and 0-day exploit targeted scanners. This unique combination offers a very broad and up-to-date coverage of vulnerabilities in your applications. By using an API, you can also integrate the report data into your incident and security workflow. 

Let‚Äôs have a quick look at the architecture overview: 

Application Vulnerability Report for SAP BTP ‚Äì Architecture Overview 

Get started now! 

You can find lots of useful information in this practical hands-on blog post: 

Introducing Application Vulnerability Report for Cloud Foundry Applications ‚Äì Try It Now! 

The complete documentation is available on SAP Help Portal. 

Please note that this is a beta service available on SAP BTP for subaccounts in trial and enterprise accounts. It is currently available in the ‚Äúcf-eu10‚Äù landscape. Once the beta phase is completed, we plan to roll out the service to other regions. 

If you are interested in what‚Äôs more to come, check out the road map in SAP Road Map Explorer. 

Try it out, and we look forward to your feedback! 

 

Also make sure to join our community to learn more about the security services and features in SAP Business Technology Platform here: 

https://community.sap.com/topics/btp-security

entry.title: Issue with Unit of Measure Mapping in Document and Report Compliance for Colombia (DIAN Requirements
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We are currently configuring Document and Report Compliance (DRC) for Colombia in an SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition implementation, and we encountered an issue related to the Unit of Measure (UoM) mapping during electronic invoice generation.

While generating the invoice XML, the system retrieves the Unit_OF_Measure code from the value mapping configuration. However, we noticed that several standard SAP UoMs do not have a direct equivalent in the fiscal authority‚Äôs database (DIAN).

For example:

  • In S/4HANA Cloud, the unit ‚ÄúPI ‚Äì Piece‚Äù exists and is commonly used in logistics and sales processes.

  • However, in the DIAN catalog, there is no unit of measure for ‚Äúpiece‚Äù, only options like DPC (Dozen Pieces) and other grouped units.

This creates a mismatch, since the SAP standard UoM does not appear in the official DIAN list, and therefore it is not clear how we should properly map these units to comply with DIAN‚Äôs required XML structure.

My questions are:

  1. How should we handle UoM mapping in DRC when the DIAN catalog does not include a direct equivalent for SAP standard units such as PI (Piece)?

  2. Is there an SAP-recommended approach or a standard mapping table for Colombia that aligns S/4HANA Cloud UoMs with DIAN-approved UoMs?

  3. Is it possible (or recommended) to create a custom mapping in Value Mapping for units not listed by DIAN, or must we adapt the business process to use only DIAN-supported units?

  4. Has anyone faced this issue in previous Colombian DRC implementations, and what was the accepted solution?

Any guidance or reference to official SAP notes or documentation for Colombia‚Äôs DRC unit-of-measure mapping would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: Re: High-Volume Data Handling in SAP Integration Suite - Our Journey to 10 Million Records
entry.content:
Hi @MateuszPiotrowski ,

Thanks for your thoughtful questions ‚Äî here are the answers:

  1. The backend system is Sandoz Reporting framework application running on SAP BTP, and its API is designed to deliver very large datasets in single responses. So yes, volumes above 50k are common in this use case and pulled less than half a minute.
  2. Correct ‚Äî with the standard OData V4 adapter, the page size cannot be controlled from SAP IS.
    The adapter always respects the server-enforced pagination limit. I have updated the blog to reflect this more clearly.
  3. Also correct ‚Äî in Approach 2, ‚ÄúProcess in Pages‚Äù is unchecked, and the pagination is managed using custom logic/Groovy scripting to break the data into chunks before sending to the target.

Thanks again for the great feedback and for raising these points ‚Äî it adds valuable clarity for others working on similar scenarios.

entry.title: The Tech Stack is READY - There is so much beyond that. (TechEd 2025 presentation - Community talk)
entry.content:
Hi All

I had the pleasure of sharing some insights on AI journey for customers and partners at SAPTeched 2025 Berlin.

Let me share (the best I can in a BLOG) the content of my session.

I started by laying out that the presentation was based on a previous blog: The AI Stack Is Ready ‚Äî Are You? The Challenge No Longer Is Technology . It is worth reading for context but I diggeed deeper in my TechEd session.

Let's dive in.

From a technology perspective, a GenAI (agent building) stack needs to provide the following capabilities:

  • Flexibility of choice of LLMs
  • Secure AI
  • RAG scenarios
  • Agent Building
  • Tool supporting
  • Orchestration

And we are there. Most platforms support that, at least in some way. That is true for SAP BTP and many others.

So we can consider that, the basic tools needed are provided. We can and should be able to start building.

Particularly around SAP, the latest TechEd announcements highlight the fast pace of innovation. More and more is coming.

MCP Support + ABAP LLM

RPT-1 and many other nice improvements

From a LLM perspective, the models keep getting better both in raw performance, Speed and cost.

As they keep getting better, a wrong approach would to say, the current models are not good enough or that we will decide to wait for next version. Believe me, you can get GPT6 performance today..... Let me explain.

Welcome TEST TIME COMPUTE

By applying some techniques that basically force the model to work harder at the question, will increase the performance.

An example of this is to ask for a brief answer vs compare that to an application that first determines a plan, proof it, execute it, revise and summarize the response. This is the principle of reasoning that are now more and more embedded in the SOTA (state of the art) LLMs, but you can keep pushing further....

SO, WHAT IS THE POINT MR. LEO???

Lets focus the discussion elsewhere. THE PROBLEM IS NO LONGER A TECHNICAL ONE.

Reality check

There are multiple reasons why that is the case. FIRST ONE is that the title of the article is misleading: It should be written 95% of the companies fail to demonstrate value. Sure a good chunk of that is due to use cases that delivered no or little value, true, but there is more to that story. 

In short:

  • Expectations are often not properly set;
  • It is natural that we get a high number if vailures - We are all experimenting and in this space, fail fast is the norm
  • There often a suboptimal approach (more on that later)
  • AND YES, it is hard to demonstrate value (methodology and tooling)

Lets set expectations right on very common misconceptions:

In ABAP you write 3 * 3 and the result will ALWAYS be 9 - This is deterministic

In GenAI (like with humans) it is probabilistic. The answer is 9 with 99.9999% prob. In other words, ask 5 billion people the same question and you won't get 100% either.

Garbage in = garbage out! This could not be more true in GenAI. If you data, assumptions or instructions are poor, expect S**t

And how many times I've heard:

Bus:"Lets put AI to solve the problem"

Tech:"describe me the problem?"

Bus: "AI should"figure it out" 

If you can't even explain the problem you are trying to solve it will be impossible to solve it.

Also, AI is not band-aid

Putting AI on a messy process will get you, well, a messy process with AI...

NOW, let focus on the IDEATION problem....

There is a reason why EVERY SINGLE VENDOR out there is after the "business cases". Good, valid, appealing and above all universal use cases are HARD to come by.

The nature of the game is, try often, fail fast, big return will come over time

In that process of getting your feet wet, you will try and mature your AI budgeting process.

Also, from a development perspective, as it is highly volatile, we recommend and approach from IDEA to POC to MVP to eventually PRODUT. Stepping stones.

In the ideation process, you need to evaluate the ideas in FEASIBILITY and VALUE. Ideally the Easiest and that will drive most business value will come to the top.

 

And how do you get there? 

Representation = You need tech folks who know the tech capabilities WITH the business folks who know the current business challenges.

Appraoch = BOTTOM UP approach is one where the ideation is around ideas to improve current processes while a BOTTOM UP approach is one where we re-think the process entirely with the new possibilities this technology brings

Also, effective enterprises adopt AI in 3 strategic levels

While company sets corporate wide transformational initiatives, departments should have their own plans and internal investments complemented by individuals trained and empowered to drive innovation in their own day to day.

 

First determine a goal or a measurable outcome, establish a target and put in place what is required to measure it.

Only then, you will be able to demonstrate return on your investment (or not).

Understand now why 95% AI pilots fail ? üòâ

entry.title: Multinline in Workflow tasks
entry.content:
Hallo experts,

I'm facing a problem with a mutltiline output in workflow description.

I'm using a class method to generate html output.
&ZCL_TEST_WF_UTIL.RENDER_HTML()&


If I call the instance method in the transfer phase and assign it to a multiline variable , i can output all lines of it in the workitem description
with this expression:

&HTML1[]&


In order to regenerate the data each time I call up the task, I want to put the call in the description itself.

For this expression, the call works, but only the first line is shown:

&ZCL_TEST_WF_UTIL.RENDER_HTML()&


The followings expressions are not interpreted as a method call, the expressions themselves will be shown in the output:

&ZCL_TEST_WF_UTIL.RENDER_HTML().LINE&

&ZCL_TEST_WF_UTIL.RENDER_HTML().LINE[]&

&ZCL_TEST_WF_UTIL.RENDER_HTML().LINE##&


Does anyone have any ideas how to solve this problem? A container element can be marked as multiline, but not the method call.

entry.title: RAP Fiori Elements app shows on create Zero GUID instead of value help text
entry.content:
Hello,

I have a RAP Fiori Elements App in SAP_BASIS 757.

I have a guid for a DC in my table and a value help for that. The value help works as expected and the reading text is shown in the field on the object page. BUT if I create a new record I initially see the zero guid '0000000-0000...' in the field until I select a DC from the value help. The guid is raw(16).

In my Root View I have an association:

association [0..1] to ZC_DISTR_CNTR_VH as _dc on $projection.DcNonMerchandise = _dc.DCKey


The related attributes in the root view are defined:

      @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{
        entity: {
          name: 'ZC_DISTR_CNTR_VH',
          element: 'DCKey'
        }
      }]
      @ObjectModel.text.association: '_dc'
      @ObjectModel.text.element: ['DcNonMerchandiseText']
      @ui.textArrangement: #TEXT_ONLY      
      @EndUserText.label: 'Non Merchandise DC'
      dc_non_merchandise    as DcNonMerchandise,

      @ui.hidden: true
      _dc.DCId              as DcNonMerchandiseText,

The view for the value help:

define view entity ZC_DISTR_CNTR_VH
  as select distinct from ZI_DISTR_CNTR as dist
  association [1..1] to ZI_DSPDTREL as _dspdtrel on dist.ext_loc_id = _dspdtrel.dc_merchandise
{
      @ui.hidden: true
      @EndUserText.label: 'Distribution Center'
      @search.defaultSearchElement: true
      @search.fuzzinessThreshold: 0.8
      @ObjectModel.text.element: ['DCId']
      @ui.textArrangement: #TEXT_ONLY
      @search.ranking: #HIGH

entry.title: How Research-Driven UX Helped Us Rethink Navigation for a Complex Enterprise Tool
entry.content:
Introduction

In one of my recent UX projects, I worked on redesigning a workflow used by technical users who handle complex data investigations. The original experience was functional but had clear opportunities for simplification, clarity, and better navigation.

Rather than redesigning the interface directly, the goal was to understand how these users think, move, and decide within the system and then let that shape the experience.

Step 1: Starting with What Exists : Early Demos & Initial Exploration

The project began with a walkthrough of the existing prototype. I reviewed:

  • How users accessed information

  • Where they navigated frequently

  • Points where decisions were unclear

  • Screens that required multiple clicks or caused backtracking

This helped me capture the real workflow behind the UI, rather than the UI itself.

Step 2: Mapping the User Journey to Identify Pain Points

Before making any changes, I created a detailed user journey map that documented:

  • Tasks users perform in sequence

  • What they expect to see at each step

  • Where confusion or delays occur

  • Opportunities to reduce switches, clicks, or cognitive load

The journey map made the pain points visible, not just for me, but for PMs, engineers, and anyone involved in shaping the product.

Step 3: Rapid Prototyping & Exploring Better Navigation

Using the journey map as the foundation, I quickly moved into rapid prototyping.

The goal wasn‚Äôt pixel-perfect UI.
The goal was speed to explore different navigation patterns that addressed the pain points we uncovered.

Some directions focused on reducing context switching.
Others explored how users could compare information side-by-side.
A few aimed to streamline the decision-making path entirely.

These early prototypes helped us move from abstract pain points to tangible solutions.

Step 4: A/B Testing to Validate Concepts

Once the prototypes were ready, I collaborated with a UX researcher to validate our assumptions.
We ran A/B tests comparing:

  • The different newly proposed navigation structures and workflows

We observed where users hesitated, which flow felt more natural, and how efficiently they completed tasks. We gathered understanding around both qualitative and quantitative insights.
This provided evidence of what actually worked and not what we assumed would work.

Step 5: Using Research to Align with PMs and EMs

Introducing a new navigation approach affects multiple teams, so alignment was essential.

Instead of presenting screens or defending a direction, we revisited the research together:

  • Journey maps showing where users slowed down

  • A/B testing sessions revealing which flow reduced confusion

  • Clear connections between user needs and proposed changes

Seeing real user behavior made the conversation simple.
The redesigned flow became a shared decision, supported by everyone‚Äôs perspectives.

While the product is still under development, the research process itself has already shaped the direction of the design and improved collaboration across the team.

Closing Thoughts

This project reminded me how powerful research becomes when it‚Äôs integrated into every step of the design process.
Journey mapping, rapid prototyping, and A/B testing didn't just validate the UX , they helped the entire team arrive at a shared understanding of what users truly need.

entry.title: Re: LICENSE_EXPIRED Error during S/4 Hana Application Server installation
entry.content:
Hello Yanik,

in hana environment you always have a systemdb and a tenantdb. tenant is the database where your SAP system or other application is running. Systemdb is the database which is for database system only, there is no sap system in this systemdb. You can run multiple tenandb's under one systemdb.

when you install hana there is only the systemdb at the beginning lets say systemdb@B10 (B10 is your HANA System ID, like a sap system) or anything else. systemdb is running in default on 3<instancenr>15 , first tenant ist running on 3<instancenr>13 and so on.

It is the same point what eason_chen mentioned with global and local licenses. you can have one global license in systemdb which is applicable for all tenantdb's or you have local licenses for dedicated tenantdb

br

entry.title: End-to-End AMDP Exception Handling: From HANA Development in ADT to ABAP Report Execution
entry.content:
1. Introduction 

 In modern SAP applications, performance-critical logic is increasingly pushed down to SAP HANA using AMDP (ABAP Managed Database Procedures). 
While AMDPs offer high performance and seamless interaction with HANA SQL Script, developers often struggle with exception handling, especially when integrating AMDP logic with CDS views and ABAP reports. This blog explains how to design an AMDP method with proper exceptions, how to consume it from ABAP, and which scenarios require CDS table functions. 
By the end, you will have a clear understanding of how to manage AMDP exceptions in real-world projects. 

2. Business Requirement 

A business user wants to extract sales order header (VBAK) data based on flexible filter conditions. 
The requirement includes: 

  • Running SQL Script logic directly on HANA for performance. 
  • Passing dynamic filters (WHERE conditions). 
  • Handling DB errors gracefully. 
  • Returning meaningful messages to the user if data is missing or if invalid filters are passed. 

To meet this, we design: 

  • An AMDP class containing SQL Script logic. 
  • A table function CDS to expose AMDP results at HANA level. (Optional based on architecture) 
  • A simple ABAP report calling the AMDP method and capturing exceptions. 

3.Technical Components 

This solution involves the following SAP artifacts: 

ABAP Objects 

ABAP Class (AMDP) 

  • Name: ZAMDP_EXCEPTION_CLASS_A 
  • Interface: IF_AMDP_MARKER_HDB 
  • Method: GET_DATA 
  • Custom SQL Script exception handling using SIGNAL 

ABAP Report 

  • Name: ZAMDP_EXCEPTIONS_S 
  • Builds WHERE clause 
  • Calls AMDP 
  • Catches CX_AMDP_ERROR 
  • Displays results in AL

4.Application Flow 

  • User runs report ZAMDP_EXCEPTIONS_S. 
  • User enters one or more VBTYP values. 
  • ABAP loops over the select-options and calls AMDP. 
  • AMDP performs: -
  • Record count 
  • Exception handling 
  • Data retrieval 
  • If an exception occurs 
    ‚Üí ABAP catches CX_AMDP_ERROR 
    ‚Üí Displays meaningful message 
  • If data exists 
    • ‚Üí Report prints or displays ALV 

 

5.Key Logic Implementation 

5.1 AMDP Class Definition

CLASS zamdp_exception_class_a DEFINITION PUBLIC. 
PUBLIC SECTION. 
INTERFACES if_amdp_marker_hdb.
TYPES: tt_sales TYPE TABLE OF vbak WITH EMPTY KEY. 
METHODS get_data 
IMPORTING 
VALUE(iv_vbtyp) TYPE vbak-vbtyp DEFAULT '' " default required 
EXPORTING 
VALUE(et_final) TYPE tt_sales 
RAISING 
cx_amdp_error. 
ENDCLASS.

5.2 AMDP Method Implementation (SQL Script) 

CLASS zamdp_exception_class_a IMPLEMENTATION. 
METHOD get_data 
BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
FOR HDB 
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
OPTIONS READ-ONLY 
USING vbak. 
DECLARE lv_count INTEGER; 
-- Count rows 
SELECT COUNT(*) INTO lv_count 
FROM vbak 
WHERE vbtyp = :iv_vbtyp; 
-- Raise custom exception 
IF :lv_count = 0 THEN 
SIGNAL SQL_ERROR_CODE 10001 
SET MESSAGE_TEXT = 'No data found for given VBTYP'; 
END IF; 
-- Fetch data 
et_final = 
SELECT * 
FROM vbak 
WHERE vbtyp = :iv_vbtyp; 
ENDMETHOD. 
ENDCLASS.

5.3 ABAP Report: Selection Screen 

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*& Report ZAMDP_EXCEPTIONS_S 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
REPORT zamdp_exceptions_s. 
TABLES: vbak. 
" Select-options for VBTYP 
SELECT-OPTIONS s_vbtyp FOR vbak-vbtyp.

5.4 AMDP Object and result Table  

DATA obj_amdp TYPE REF TO zamdp_exception_class_a. 
DATA it_final TYPE zamdp_exception_class_a=>tt_sales. 
" Create AMDP instance 
obj_amdp = NEW zamdp_exception_class_a( ).

5.5 Calling AMDP Method with Exception Handling & Displaying Data in ALV 

TRY. 
    CLEAR it_final. 
    LOOP AT s_vbtyp INTO DATA(ls_vbtyp). 
      IF ls_vbtyp-sign = 'I' AND ls_vbtyp-option = 'EQ'. 
        CALL METHOD obj_amdp->get_data 
          EXPORTING 
            iv_vbtyp = ls_vbtyp-low 
          IMPORTING 
            et_final = DATA(lt_data).   "temp table 
        " Append data 
        APPEND LINES OF lt_data TO it_final. 
      ENDIF. 
    ENDLOOP. 
    " If some data exists ‚Üí Display it 
    IF it_final IS NOT INITIAL. 
      WRITE:/ 'VBELN', 10 'AUART', 20 'VKORG', 30 'VTWEG', 40 'SPART', 
              50 'KUNNR', 60 'ERDAT', 70 'ERNAM', 80 'VBTYP'. 
      LOOP AT it_final INTO DATA(ls_row). 
        WRITE: / ls_row-vbeln, 10 ls_row-auart, 20 ls_row-vkorg, 
                 30 ls_row-vtweg, 40 ls_row-spart, 50 ls_row-kunnr, 
                 60 ls_row-erdat, 70 ls_row-ernam, 80 ls_row-vbtyp. 
      ENDLOOP. 
    ENDIF. 
  CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lx_err). 
    " Get HANA error text 
    DATA(lv_text) = lx_err->if_message~get_longtext( ).  
    WRITE:/ lv_text. 
ENDTRY.

6.Sample Output 
6.1 If Exception was Not Raised (Data Retrieval )

6.2 Raising Exception

7.Conclusion 

This technical implementation demonstrates Exception handling in AMDP is essential for building stable, performant HANA-optimized applications. 
A well-structured design connecting CDS + AMDP + ABAP ensures: 

  • Clean separation between data retrieval (AMDP class) and presentation (ABAP report). 
  • Handling exceptions in AMDP and propagating them in ABAP. 
  • Using dynamic filters from select-options in SQL Script. 
  • Cleaner integration between HANA SQL Script and ABAP 
  • Displaying results efficiently in ALV tables. 
  • Providing a robust and user-friendly solution for sales order header analysis. 

This approach can be extended for other database-intensive operations in SAP HANA using ABAP and AMDP.

CLASS zamdp_exception_class_a DEFINITION PUBLIC.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES if_amdp_marker_hdb.
    TYPES: tt_sales TYPE TABLE OF vbak WITH EMPTY KEY.
    METHODS get_data
      IMPORTING
        VALUE(iv_vbtyp) TYPE vbak-vbtyp DEFAULT ''   " default required
      EXPORTING
        VALUE(et_final) TYPE tt_sales
      RAISING
        cx_amdp_error.
ENDCLASS.
CLASS zamdp_exception_class_a IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD get_data
    BY DATABASE PROCEDURE
    FOR HDB
    LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
    OPTIONS READ-ONLY
    USING vbak.
    DECLARE lv_count INTEGER;
    -- Count rows
    SELECT COUNT(*) INTO lv_count
      FROM vbak
      WHERE vbtyp = :iv_vbtyp;
    -- Raise custom exception
    IF :lv_count = 0 THEN
        SIGNAL SQL_ERROR_CODE 10001
          SET MESSAGE_TEXT = 'No data found for given VBTYP';
    END IF;
    -- Fetch data
    et_final =
      SELECT *
      FROM vbak
      WHERE vbtyp = :iv_vbtyp;
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZAMDP_EXCEPTIONS_S
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT zamdp_exceptions_s.
TABLES: vbak.
" Select-options for VBTYP
SELECT-OPTIONS s_vbtyp FOR vbak-vbtyp.
" AMDP object and result table
DATA obj_amdp TYPE REF TO zamdp_exception_class_a.
DATA it_final TYPE zamdp_exception_class_a=>tt_sales.
" Create AMDP instance
obj_amdp = NEW zamdp_exception_class_a( ).
TRY.
    CLEAR it_final.
    LOOP AT s_vbtyp INTO DATA(ls_vbtyp).
      IF ls_vbtyp-sign = 'I' AND ls_vbtyp-option = 'EQ'.

        CALL METHOD obj_amdp->get_data
          EXPORTING
            iv_vbtyp = ls_vbtyp-low
          IMPORTING
            et_final = DATA(lt_data).   "temp table
        " Append data
        APPEND LINES OF lt_data TO it_final.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
    " If some data exists ‚Üí Display it
    IF it_final IS NOT INITIAL.
      WRITE:/ 'VBELN', 10 'AUART', 20 'VKORG', 30 'VTWEG', 40 'SPART',
              50 'KUNNR', 60 'ERDAT', 70 'ERNAM', 80 'VBTYP'.
      LOOP AT it_final INTO DATA(ls_row).
        WRITE: / ls_row-vbeln, 10 ls_row-auart, 20 ls_row-vkorg,
                 30 ls_row-vtweg, 40 ls_row-spart, 50 ls_row-kunnr,
                 60 ls_row-erdat, 70 ls_row-ernam, 80 ls_row-vbtyp.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDIF.
  CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lx_err).
    " Get HANA error text
    DATA(lv_text) = lx_err->if_message~get_longtext( ).
    WRITE:/ lv_text.
ENDTRY.

entry.title: Emergency: Affecting 100 people,Acct cant enter into the SAP &Cant select the BR Acct table as key
entry.content: The Brazilian National Public Cloud System has activated the local Brazilian chart of accounts. As a Brazilian group company, the Chinese entity must map its group-level accounts to the system to align with the local Brazilian accounts (maintaining two sets of accounts: one for the group and one for Brazil). 1. When configuring the chart of accounts, the Brazilian company's operational accounts are automatically assigned the YCOA standard. The YCBR Brazilian chart of accounts serves as an alternative chart of accounts (the system should designate which accounts belong under the group-level chart and which under the local Brazilian chart).

entry.title: Defining Safe AI: Transparency within ideation and validation
entry.content:
Introduction 

Aviation safety became non-negotiable because stakeholders agreed on a clear definition: keeping humans alive and systems operational. For AI, the definition is less obvious and varies by use case. We define AI safety as systems operating within intended boundaries without causing harm: technical, ethical, or societal, as beautifully explained by Bettina Laugwitz in her introductory blogpost of this series (Keep the blue side up: Building trust in AI throug... - SAP Community). This means being lawful, ethical, and robust, echoing the principles outlined in global AI governance frameworks such as ISO/IEC 42001 and related regulations such as the EU AI Act. ISO/IEC 42001:2023 - AI management systems, EU Artificial Intelligence Act | Up-to-date developments and analyses of the EU AI Act, Standards, frameworks, and legislation for artificial intelligence (AI) transparency | AI and Ethics 

For ‚ÄúTransparency & Explainability‚Äù in AI systems to progress beyond aspirational slogans; they must be engineered into the product, the pipeline, and day-to-day operations, with clear roles for every stakeholder. Overview of transparency and inspectability mechanisms to achieve accountability of artificial intelligence systems | Data & Policy | Cambridge Core, Evaluating Transparency in the Development of Artificial Intelligence Systems: A Systematic Literature Review. Let's look at how.

AI's Captain and the crew: Stakeholder Requirement Mapping 

In aviation, roles are clearly defined: pilots, air traffic controllers, maintenance crew, and cabin staff, each have specific responsibilities and access to information. Pilots see cockpit instruments not the engineering schematics; maintenance teams get technical manuals, not passenger safety cards. This layered approach ensures clarity without unnecessary information overload. Similarly, transparency must be tailored to the different roles. Engineers need deep technical details while end users need simple actionable explanations of the system they are interacting with. 

What does it include: A persona mapping exercise should be conducted in the early ideation stage for the AI feature to identify stakeholders including engineers, product owners, compliance teams, end users, etc. and their transparency needs should be detailed out. Role-based access to information should follow the least privilege principle. Further to this mapping exercise, there should be a clear assignment of accountabilities related to transparency checkpoints(decided on a case to case basis). Questions like: who approves product updates, who updates the documentation, who monitors compliance, etc. Should be answered by the use case team and related mapping should be embedded into the design documents and backlog items early in the lifecycle. 

In practice: An established approach to identify user roles, users‚Äô objectives, and their (information) needs is conducting early-stage design workshops (e. g. following the SAP AppHaus‚Äô Business AI Explore or Design workshop methodology).  

Navigating tough terrains: Classifying use cases 

For planning appropriate contingency measures, scenarios within aviation sector are classified into different categories, based on weather conditions, passenger load, aircraft readiness, etc. Similarly, it is important to classify AI use cases into different categories early on to decide the extent of transparency measures to be implemented within the use case to mitigate the associated risks appropriately. 

What does it include: This would include classification based on low, medium, high impact (on individuals for e.g.), critically of the sector in which the use case is operationalized (HR, Finance being on the higher criticality side), automation levels (fully automated decision-making being highly critical), tool access (especially for agent use cases, in order to avoid cascading harms), regulatory exposure (For e.g. healthcare being highly regulated), etc. Considering this classification, for appropriate transparency: 

  • Human oversight mechanisms should be appropriately adjusted.  
  • Retention period for the audit logs should be proportional to the impact. 
  • High impact use cases should have rollback mechanisms and hence related documentation. 
  • Impact should be linked to internal responsible AI policies around transparency. 

In practice: At SAP, every AI use case goes through the AI Ethics Review process that categorizes them into different categories according to the respective ethical impact. A detailed blogpost around the AI ethics governance process at SAP will be published soon as part of this blogpost series around AI transparency. For now, to learn more about how the process works, please refer to the SAP AI Ethics Handbook (chapter ‚ÄúPrinciples into action‚Äù) in which categorization criteria and governance setup are described in more details (or watch the ‚ÄúGoverning AI Ethics at SAP‚Äù lesson of the SAP Learning Journey ‚ÄúPutting AI Ethics into Practice at SAP‚Äù).  

AI's Pre‚Äëflight checklists: Transparency & explainability prerequisites 

Airplanes are never shipped without a complete ticked off checklist. Similarly, AI features should never be shipped without passing a Transparency & explainability checklist. This list should also be passed down the chain to relevant stakeholders who can then use this at different checkpoints and keep an eye out for deviations and document these parameters. This not only includes architectural transparency, but also other components of overall engineering side of AI development related quality checks focusing on transparency and explainability which should be provided to relevant stakeholders within the enterprise and to the system admins at the customer/user side. 

What does it include: A pre-flight checklist for AI transparency should mandate architectural transparency by documenting system purpose, data sources, model type, and limitations; confirm explainability readiness wherever AI influences outcomes; and verify compliance hooks aligned with regulatory anchors like the EU AI Act. This checklist must integrate into the development workflow by linking items to backlog tools and making transparency a release gate item. No feature ships without proof of appropriate transparency and explainability. It should also be distributed across stakeholders including architects, QA, product owners, and system admins, with checkpoints for deviations during lifecycle changes (something on the lines of SAP Design System Guidelines). Alongside this, evidence packs should be stored in a central repository linked to project management tools for auditability. Finally, for high-risk AI systems, add enhanced monitoring and troubleshooting documentation for deployment and operations to ensure resilience and compliance. 

In practice: Transparency and explainability requirements are very different for different application contexts, situations and user personas (as explained in this blogpost: Trustworthy AI: How to make artificial intelligenc... - SAP Community). The SAP Fiori Design Guidelines for explainable AI take this variety of expectations into account by differentiating between L1/L2/L3 explanations: Level 1: Minimum explanation level for quick overview; Level 2: Condensed view of the relevant properties, amounts and contextual information; Level 3: Extended report specifically for advanced users covering details around the AI performance, further context and conditions for monitoring AI operations). Applied to an SAP use case, the need for end-user transparency is very obvious when it comes to HR related contexts, e. g. candidate analysis in recruiting. In the Learning Journey lesson ‚ÄúEnsuring Explainability in HR AI Systems‚Äù, our experts share how the team addressed the requirements during implementation.   

Closing 

Transparency isn‚Äôt a checklist you tick once, it‚Äôs a culture that starts at ideation and validation and continues through every stage of the AI lifecycle. By embedding stakeholder mapping, risk classification, and compliance gates early, we create a foundation where trust is engineered, not promised. These steps ensure that transparency is not an afterthought but a design principle that shapes every decision.  

In the next blog post, we‚Äôll move beyond planning and delve deeper into practice, exploring how transparency can be operationalized during realization, productization, and operations stages, with concrete engineering patterns. Together, these two parts outline key engineering practices for integrating transparency into AI systems aligned with the principles of lawfulness, ethics, and robustness. 

 

Let's keep sharing how AI transparency helps keep_the_blue_side_up

 

Stay tuned for the next part of this blogpost with further deep dive into the engineering practices around AI transparency!!

 

References and further readings

AI Transparency Blogpost Series 

  • Introductory Blogpost:  Keep the blue side up: Building trust in AI throug... - SAP Community 
  • Explainability Blogpost: Trustworthy AI: How to make artificial intelligenc... - SAP Community 

AI Transparency @SAP 

  • Design workshops: https://apphaus.sap.com/resource/business-ai-design-workshop; https://apphaus.sap.com/resource/business-ai-explore-workshop 
  • Testing and Monitoring Features within Agent Builder: Joule Studio | AI Agent Builder | Product tour 
  • Explainable AI Design Guidelines: https://www.sap.com/design-system/fiori-design-web/v1-120/foundations/ai-and-joule-design/guidelines/explainable-ai 

Responsible AI Assets 

  • Blogpost explaining Trustworthy AI: Trustworthy AI: How to make artificial intelligenc... - SAP Community 
  • SAP AI Ethics Policy and Handbook: Responsible AI | SAP 
  • Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/putting-ai-ethics-into-practice-at-sap 
  • Compliance & certification information-SAP Trust Center: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center.html 

Aviation Safety Research 

  • Integrated Framework for Implementing Safety-I and Safety-II Principles in Aviation Safety Management 
  • Enhancing modern aviation systems through systems engineering principles and emerging technologies 

Regulations and governance frameworks 

  • ISO/IEC 42001:2023 - AI management systems 
  • EU Artificial Intelligence Act | Up-to-date developments and analyses of the EU AI Act

entry.title: What is HANA Calculation View Modeling and is it for me?
entry.content:
SAP HANA Calculation View modeling was introduced with the launch of SAP HANA back in 2010 and has become one of the most popular and sought-after skills in SAP Analytics. If you are wondering if this topic is for you, and you would like a brief description of what is it and what can be achieved, then read on.

SAP HANA Calculation View modeling is your tool of choice for modeling analytic scenarios with SAP HANA Cloud. It allows preprocessing and preparation of your data to harvest them in analytic clients. With calculation views you implement your business logic using an intuitive graphical interface.

Graphical Calculation View Editor

 

By the close integration of calculation views into SAP HANA you leverage the full potential of the performance of SAP HANA using several pruning and many more techniques.

Some Performance Optimization Options

 

Being fully integrated into SAP HANA development tooling you benefit from enterprise ready lifecycle management.

Integrated Version Control

Similarly, you can count on enterprise ready features such as multi-language support.

Support of Multiple Languages

 

SAP is working on deepening the bidirectional integration with SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) so that calculation views seamlessly integrate into BDC modeling while at the same time opening the venue to integrate BDC data products into HANA Cloud via calculation views.

 

Reporting on calculation views is pretty flexible. You can use SQL statements, SQL based tools, or you can build on the SAP ecosystem around SAP Cloud Analytics. This gives you the free choice around analytic clients. Calculation views automatically generate metadata during their deployment so that analytic clients know how to best access, display, and analyze the data. For example, information about expected prompts or type of data and their meaning are available as metadata.

 

Documentation about Meta Data

The graphical building blocks of calculation views make it easy to extend your logic and to visualize the implemented logic to your stakeholders.

 

Imagine you are asked to provide up to date sales data every morning. Instead of handcrafting a SQL statement you create a calculation view that combines the relevant technical tables in joins. This way you neither have to hand over a SQL statement nor do you need to assume that the stakeholder understands your SQL statement. Instead you point your stakeholder to the created calculation view. By enriching the calculation view with semantically meaningful data, e.g., business partner data you ensure that the report is grounded in a meaningful context.

Calculation view modeling has developed from the on-premise SAP HANA Studio tooling via the on premise browser based SAP Web IDE for HANA to the cloud tooling SAP Business Application Studio. It is embedded into the SAP Build Code environment to make sure that you can integrate it with all the other BTP development options.

Target User

HANA calculation views are the first stop if you want to encode your technical knowledge about data and tables into an easy to consume model. You can integrate data from different sources either directly with calculation views using the remote capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud or you integrate your calculation views into SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to leverage the ecosystem of BDC with its enhanced capabilities to enrich calculation views with additional business semantics. If you are a data expert with a familiarity to databases, calculation views are your tool of choice to leverage database performance techniques while creating semantically meaningful units of reporting. Whether your purpose is to analyse large data sets or your purpose is to provide meaningful analytic reports - calculation views are your choice: Calculation views provide an easy and flexible way to build up complex scenarios in a structured manner and keep the scenarios easily adaptable and maintainable to bring the required agility into your development process.

Got interested? Read about new innovations around calculation views by visiting the blog on new calculation view features

Visit the FAQ blog for frequently asked questions

entry.title: Re: Introducing Application Vulnerability Report for Cloudfoundry Applications ‚Äì Try It Now!
entry.content:
Hi @Harjyot, 

thanks for your questions! To answer them:

Does the service (or its API) cover scanning of HTML5/custom UI5 applications deployed in SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry) and also in on‚Äëpremise landscapes, or is it limited to CF runtime apps?

Our service scans applications deployed on the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry runtime and does not cover on-premise landscapes.

Regarding HTML5/UI5 applications, they are covered under the following conditions:

  • The application must be deployed on the Cloud Foundry runtime.
  • The scan focuses on identifying vulnerabilities within the application's open-source components and dependencies.

 

Can we retrieve a list of direct and transitive npm/pip packages (from package-lock.json and similar), plus severity findings per component via the API? What output formats are supported?

Yes, the API provides the necessary information to address those needs.

  • List of Packages: The API response includes a packageNames field, which is an array containing the names of the components where vulnerabilities were found. Our underlying scan identifies vulnerabilities across the entire dependency tree.
  • Severity Findings: The API gives detailed severity information for each finding through:
    • maxCvss: highest CVSS score, providing a standard numerical severity rating.
    • priority: simplified priority level.
    • activeCves: list of specific CVEs associated with the component.
    • description and recommendation: textual details about the vulnerability and how to remediate it.
  • Output Format: The API supports the JSON format for its output, as seen by the data model.

Frequency: the blog mentions weekly scans. Are there options to configure a different cadence, or trigger on-demand scans?

Right now, the scans are run on a weekly basis but we have plans to incorporate a more frequent scanning regiment. 

We already run a custom scanning pipeline and would love to better understand integration paths (API rate limits, auth, audit logs) and whether we can submit our package-lock.json as input to reduce false negatives for UI5/Node/Python stacks.

API findings are returned in the format:

{

  "findings": [{

    "id*": "string",

    "sourceId*": "string",

    "globalAccountId*": "string",

    "subAccountId*": "string",

    "findingId*": "string",

    "description*": "string",

    "recommendation*": "string",

    "cfOrganizationId": "string",

    "cfOrganizationName": "string",

    "appId": "string",

    "appName": "String",

    "lastFound": "Timestamp",

    "firstFound": "Timestamp",

    "assetContext": "string",

    "assetLink": "string",

    "spaceId": "string",

    "spaceName": "string",

    "packageNames": "string[]",

    "activeCves" : "string[]",

    "maxCvss" : "decimal",

    "platform": "string",

    "maxCvssVector": "string",

    "sourceRuleId": "string",

    "priority": "string"

  }]

}

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud, add-in for Microsoft Excel - New high-volume mode
entry.content:
Since the first release in 2020, SAP Analytics Cloud, add-in for Microsoft Excel has matured to a powerful analytics and planning client embedded in Microsoft Excel.

After adding features like data point commenting, restricted measures or VBA support, we see a lot of customers using the add-in for highly critical business processes such as planning.

However, extracting a high number of cells (>500.000) has led to some challenges. The main challenge is a memory limitation that browsers support for one instance: 4GB. And note: even within Excel desktop, the add-in is running in a browser runtime (i.e., WebView2 or WebKit2). With the given architecture, the add-in could hit this limit easily with about 500.000 to 1.000.000 cells. When this limit was hit, Excel restarts the add-in.

There are scenarios where you need to combine detailed information and the flexibility of Excel calculations. We have been approached by many customers to increase the number of cells that can be displayed in SAC add-in. After a thorough analysis, we chose the way to bypass the SAP Analytics Cloud table (used in the story), which is currently the basis to render the table in Excel. It provides lots of features like number formatting, frontend calculations (insert new rows/columns including formulas), planning and many more. The disadvantage is that this SAC table consumes more memory than necessary for Excel use cases. In the SAC story, this is not so much of a problem as the tables can be read in paging. In Excel, however, the entire table needs to be loaded to support calculations on it.

Our approach is to optimize memory usage by directly reading the pure data information and adding some features on top which were previously offered by SAC table. We decided to have an option to switch from the standard table (using SAC table API) to a memory- and performance-optimized version of it (and back).

In the first version we limited the features for the high-volume mode to the essential ones. For example, planning is not supported ‚Äì as we assume no planner works on input sheets with millions of cells. Also frontend calculations and comments are not supported in this mode. There are also some limitations that we plan to fix soon such as properties.

In our internal test scenarios we have seen memory consumption reduced ‚Äì in comparison to the standard mode ‚Äì by up to factor 10. We could also see performance improvements (end to end) by up to 30% (note that backend and rendering time stay the same, only calculation time is reduced). Of course, for smaller result sets, the difference between the mode is not significant.

In MDS (HANA multi-dimensional services), you will also hit some default values such as the maximum result set size which is set to 1 million cells (result_set_size_max_default). In order to support larger datasets, SAC add-in overrides this value in high-volume mode with the absolute maximum of 10 million cells (result_set_size_max_limit, see SAP note 2770570). The other value for cell size (only needed for internal server calculations) is not changed. As the memory allocation has been optimized, you can also add several tables with altogether more than 10 million cells into the workbook, while for one table the maximum stays with 10 million cells.

In order to activate the high-volume mode, you can use the context menu of the table.

You can switch back and forth between the modes. The default for new tables is the standard mode. You can use the pause/refresh feature for adding a new table and switch them to high-volume mode before the table is rendered.

When comparing performance, you can use the profiling information that you can activate in the workbook preferences.

This generates an additional sheet that provides information how much time is spent in different layers and how much memory is used.

entry.title: Re: Generic IDoc Outbound flow in Cloud Integration Pipeline
entry.content:
Hello @iignatius,

If you want to consume an event from SAP Event Mesh in an SAP Cloud Integration iFlow (rather than delivering the event directly to the receiver) you can use the Pipeline Framework.

How to implement depends on the event type:

  • Notification events: If you need data enrichment (for example, lookups or formatting), use Step 03 (Inbound Conversion) to enrich the payload and then Step 07.
  • Data events: If you must transform the message or deliver it via a protocol that Event Mesh does not support, use only a scenario‚Äëspecific Step 07 (Outbound) to perform the transformation and handle protocol-specific delivery to the target receiver.

Key difference versus IDocs:

  • With IDocs, you configure the BD64 distribution model in the sender backend for each receiver.
  • With events, you publish once (‚Äúfire and forget‚Äù) to Event Mesh, which routes to all subscribed receivers - no per-receiver communication IDoc is needed in the backend.
  • If a receiver cannot consume events directly from Event Mesh, you can place Cloud Integration in between and leverage the Pipeline Framework for enrichment, transformation, and delivery.

Hope this clarifies the approach.

entry.title: Re: üì¢ Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content:
Why restrict the choice to 2 options only?

Typically, SAP follows a generic, flexible approach, i.e. a generic, parameterized default solution, which could be overruled or adapted by customers.

I'd suggest to introduce a Fiori app to cover simple cases plus a BAdI to cover specific requirements, so that a customer could implement its needs. This BAdI could receive the following input parameters as context:

  • System/Runtime type
  • Software Component
  • ABAP Language Version
  • Object Type
  • Package
  • etc.

The result could be either a naming proposal or simply a boolean value (naming convention matched: yes/no)

For me, a Naming Convention looks like a "Business Rule for Developers" - so perhaps a corresponding framework could be used in the implementation? 

Please apply the Naming Convention to all (new) generators, e.g. for Business Configuration. Ideally the new solution offers a "Test" and "Consistency Check" feature.

entry.title: Signavio Process Insights and Process Intelligence - an unexpected journey
entry.content:
2025 is on the last mile and I'm about to finalize my work for SAP Signavio Process Analysis and Mining (PA&M). Looking back to when I started it feels like thinking about "the good old times" and "an unexpected journey", although it's only 2.5 years ago. Since then we almost tripled the number of customers and for 3 years in a row we were leaders in Gartner's Magic Quadrant. 
Did I expect that? For sure not, but in hindsight I can share my learning and my personal cook book for enterprise software development success.

When I joined Signavio Process Insights (internally known as PINS) as Chief Product Owner in August 2023 (NOW release 2505 & THEN release 2310), we were a small but mighty team of about 50 people. With just over ~330 customers, and a rather longish time frame until customers started actively using their tenants. Our growth ambition was sky-high, but the team was ready to reach for the stars. At the same time, Process Intelligence (internally known as PINT) had a similar number of customers. Our biggest challenge was changing the perception that both products were just the result of the clash between Signavio acquisition and SAP's own developed BTP solution and either the one or the other will be discontinued.

Fast forward to today: We can proudly look back on an incredible joint growth story for both solutions with tripled number of customers and we will see the solutions growing closer and closer together with every release. A very bright example of this is Plug and Gain with which we built the bridge to connect both solutions under the hood and the first step to a joint PA&M solution. And even more: I'm very proud that we are on our way for the general availability of the recently announced PA&M unification, which is the long awaited first step for the new Signavio suite user experience. 

Here is my personal cook book for software engineering success at SAP:

  1. 2309 The "old" Start Page: Start simple with high value use cases and free usage (the Discovery Edition) and then...
  2. 2311 Fiori Horizon user experience: ...make user experience consistent, by leveraging SAP Fiori as the standard for all solutions...
  3. 2402 Internationalization: ...scale globally by adding 7 new languages,...
  4. 2405 Transformation Manager: ...show progress in a 360 degree transformation initiative view in the Signavio suite ...
  5. 2407 Attribute-based authorization: ...scale for large enterprises by introducing access control on organizational level,...
  6. 2408 Plug&Gain as PINS Service and PINT Connector: ...deep integration out-of-the-box,...
  7. 2411 Personal Dashboards as start page: ...bring hidden gems to the front door, by allowing users to build dashboards for their interest topics...
  8. 2505 Improvement Opportunity Dashboards: ...explain deep insights for everybody, and retain Gartner MQ leadership in 2025... 
  9. 2509 Semantic Search (Beta): ...provide the contextual foundation for AI-Agents..

     

Here you can learn more about Process Analysis and Mining:

  1. See SAP Signavio Process Insights, Process Intelligence and Plug & Gain in action
  2. Your first steps to get started with SAP Signavio Process Insights
  3. Who do I need to involve and which challenges do I want to solve?
  4. How to start your analysis?
  5. ‚ÄúCash is King‚Äù - but how to become royal? - SAP Community
  6. Why are there two business process analysis soluti... - SAP Community
  7. Plug & Gain:
    • Plug & Gain Video Series and Plug & Gain OpenSAP
    • How to use the Plug & Gain Connector
    • Optimize financial closing process with Plug & Gain
  1. SAP Analytics Cloud Content for Process Insights
  2. SAP Learning:
    SAP Signavio Process Analysis
    SAP Signavio Process Management & Design
    SAP Signavio Solution Configuration
  3. Partner Edge (Login required): Webinar Series for Process Insights
  4. SAP Signavio Process Insights "Whats New?"
  5. SAP Signavio Process Insights Help

entry.title: Employee Central Integration with Employee Central Payroll
entry.content:
Hi everyone,
I‚Äôm currently working on an Employee Central ‚Üí Employee Central Payroll (ECP) Point-to-Point integration and I‚Äôm trying to locate the official EC to ECP Integration Workbook (Excel) provided by SAP.

I‚Äôve already reviewed the following sources:

  • SAP Help Portal documentation for EC and ECP

  • Best Practices packages (EC, ECP, Global Benefits)

  • Configuration Guides such as ‚ÄúEmployee Central Integration with Employee Central Payroll‚Äù

  • Workbooks for other areas (Time Off, Global Benefits, etc.)

However, I have not been able to find the specific Integration Workbook that includes the EC ‚Üí Payroll mapping information (pay components, wage types, PTP segments, BIB mappings, etc.).

Could someone please advise where exactly this workbook is located, or whether it is only available through:

  • Best Practices Explorer (BPX),

  • PartnerEdge,

  • SAP Customer/Implementation Assets,

Thank you!

entry.title: Inbound Process - Oriented storage control (POSC) Deconsolidation process
entry.content:
1. Configuration

1.1 Define work center

SPRO ‚Äì> IMG‚Äî> SCM Extended warehouse management ‚Äì> Extended warehouse management ‚Äì> Master Data ‚Äì> Define work center.

 Figure 1

 

1.2 Define Process-Oriented Storage process control (POSC)

SPRO ‚Äì> IMG‚Äî> SCM Extended warehouse management ‚Äì> Extended warehouse management ‚Äì> Cross-process settings ‚Äì> Warehouse Task ‚Äì> Define Process-Oriented Storage process control.

  Figure 2

3 SAP standard external steps IB01, IB02, IB03 are assigned to 3 internal process steps(UNLO,SPR,PUT)

 Figure 3

To the Warehouse assign the external process steps, source storage type and destination storage type, also destination bins.

 Figure 4

 

1.3 Check the Warehouse process type 3065 , 3060 and 1011

SPRO ‚Äì> IMG‚Äî> SCM Extended warehouse management ‚Äì> Extended warehouse management ‚Äì> Cross-process settings ‚Äì> Warehouse Task ‚Äì> Define Warehouse process type.

 Figure 5

The WPT 3065 will determine the source storage type and bin as shown above.

 Figure 6

 

1.4 Determine Warehouse process type

SPRO ‚Äì> IMG‚Äî> SCM Extended warehouse management ‚Äì> Extended warehouse management ‚Äì> Cross-process settings ‚Äì> Warehouse Task ‚Äì> Determine Warehouse process type.

 

 Figure 7

Process type determination indicator for WPT 1011 is IB that is assigned to Warehouse.

 

Process Steps

1.Create Material Master

Create materials by selecting required views.

In /n/scwm/MAT1, Maintain process type determine indicator(WPT indicator) as IB for both materials and 

Putaway control indicator 0020 for 1st product and 0021 for 2nd product as shown in figure below.

 

 Figure 8

 

2.Create purchase order

Create a purchase order in ERP system (T code ME21N), verify the vendor, plant and storage location for the entered products. The confirmation key for the PO line item should allow the creation of inbound deliveries.

 

3.Create an Inbound delivery

Create an inbound delivery in ERP system (T code VL31N),in the delivery detail screen, enter the delivery quantity.in the packing screen, pack the product into HU, since HU is a requirement for both POSC & LOSC. Once the required data is entered save the data in the inbound delivery, this will create an inbound delivery in the ERP system and will be transferred to EWM system for further processing.

 Figure 9

 

5.Maintain Inbound delivery

Maintain Inbound delivery in EWM system using T code /N/SCWM/PRDI, paste the inbound delivery created in the ERP system and execute it, do unloading and goods receipt as shown in figure 10.

 Figure 10

 

Display the Inbound delivery in the warehouse monitor (T code /N/SCWM/MON), Here 3 warehouse tasks will be created

 Figure 11

  • Warehouse task  is created in background for the step IB01 and the second step is in open status , for moving the Source HU from the source storage type 9010 to destination storage type 8010. Since Warehouse task is open based on the settings made in WPT 3060

  • Other task is created and closed, It is for moving the HU from S.type9030 to S.type 9010, it is automatically closed based on settings made in the WPT 3065.Before deconsolidation we need to confirm the warehouse task

6. Deconsolidation using T code /N/SCWM/DCONS

do the deconsolidation at 8010(work center DEKO) by breaking HU and repacking with different HU and move those to destination storage types 0020 and 0021.

Pass the HU number and then execute

 Figure 12

Before unpack we need to create the packaging material.

Enter packaging material: PALLET and execute.

 Figure 13

Now go to deconsolidation tab and enter the source HU number as shown below and click on warehouse tasks and select the task, destination HU will be automatically taken and click on execute

 Figure 14

Select the  HU and complete the deconsolidation process as shown below and repeat the same for other HU also. 

 Figure 15

Now both the tasks are open status as shown below, select line and confirm the task in background

 Figure 16

 

7. Stock check in the monitor  (T code/N/SCWM/MON)

finally in the monitor check the stock and bin, both the HU'S will be placed in the respective storage type and bin as per the POSC configuration made, as shown in figure 17.

 Figure 17

 

Conclusion:

From the above steps, one can understand how to configure Inbound Process-Oriented Storage control (POSC) In Deconsolidation process, by following the above steps one can have a clear idea on how to use POSC concept In Deconsolidation process and can implement the same depends on the  business requirement.

 

References:

https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blogs-by-members/layout-oriented-storage-contro...

www.ewmguru.com

www.sap-press.com

 

Pre requisite: Should have Basic knowledge of SAP Extended Warehouse Management.

 

Please like, share and comment for any queries through add comment button which is displayed at bottom of the blog-post.

For any queries, please post your question by using the following link

https://community.sap.com/t5/c-khhcw49343/SAP+Extended+Warehouse+Management/pd-p/0120061532080000070...

Hope this blog-post will be help full

 

Thank you

entry.title: Re: Process Overview of Client Refresh using EPI-USE method
entry.content:
HI biswanath8675

user master export-import cannot be ignored but in RISE private cloud epiuselabs have found a way to avoid SAP* . 

By default it is true that SAP* is not more provided in private cloud scenarios but it could be done for 4 hours only. 

We had a conversation with SAP

They permit the creation of a custom user cust_tc with profiles EPI-USE labs provides. 
The customer then leverages the cust_tc user to import the Client Sync extract into the business client. 

Thanks
N

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud + Sales Performance Management: Drive Sales with Clarity and Confidence
entry.content:
Imagine this: Your sales team is motivated, aligned, and focused. Quotas are clear. Incentives are fair. Performance insights are at your fingertips. That‚Äôs not a dream, it‚Äôs what happens when SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Sales Performance Management (SPM) work together.

The Challenge

Sales leaders often struggle with fragmented tools, unclear incentive plans, and limited visibility. Sellers waste time chasing numbers instead of customers. Managers lack real-time insights to coach effectively. Operations teams fight complexity instead of driving efficiency.

The Solution

SAP Sales Cloud and SAP SPM combine to deliver a single, intelligent solution. Together, they:

  • Unify insights: Compensation plans, quotas, and performance data in one place.
  • Motivate sellers: Transparent incentives and accurate earnings calculations.
  • Empower managers: Real-time dashboards for coaching and pipeline decisions.
  • Streamline operations: Automated workflows and reduced administrative overhead.

With advanced analytics and AI-driven recommendations, you can predict outcomes, adjust plans, and keep your team focused on what matters‚Äîselling.

The Outcome

When SPM is embedded into SAP Sales Cloud, productivity soars. Sellers trust the process. Managers lead with confidence. Operations run smoothly. The entire organization becomes informed, motivated, and rewarded for success.

Want to go deeper?

Explore our SAP Customer Experience Value Map and unlock guided learning, best practices, and expert support:

  • Sales Cloud Value Map ‚Äì Version 1
  • Sales Cloud Value Map ‚Äì Version 2

And if you‚Äôre ready to master incentive management, check out the Sales Performance Management TKB

entry.title: The post date of Returns Delivery can't be decided
entry.content:
Hi ,

In the  APP Manage Customer Returns , I creat Returns order  base on Invoice . The follow-up activity for returns order is Receive into plant(0001).

And than I Post Returns Delivery and confirm the inspection document . 

In the Returns Delivery , I enter the Actual Goods Movement Date is 2025-11-20 .

In the  inspection document , I enter the inspection date is 2025-11-20 .  I find that  the inspection document is Released On today (2025-12-04)

Finally I find that the Posting Date of the Returns Delivery Journal Entry  is 2025-12-04 . I can't decide the  post date of Returns Delivery .
